div.p: alright well thank you for having us
tonight it's so great to be here I as
has been said and part of a news
organization and justice watch we've
been around for about a year now our
launch was last november i believe and
we're really thrilled to be a part of
this community a lot of cool people in
this room doing cool things and I'm here
tonight to talk a little bit about what
our organization does and specifically
about a project we did this past July on
Chicago Police Department Street stops
in Chicago so yes so this is our
organization our mission we are
nonpartisan not-for-profit multimedia
journalism organization that conducts
in-depth research exposing institutional
failures that obstruct justice and
equality so like I said we've been
around for about a year now and we like
to take a look at the criminal justice
system in Chicago and then sort of use
that as a lens to explore what's going
on nationwide and the criminal justice
realm so for this project specifically
it was me and Emily Horner who's in the
back with us tonight and she's a
reporter and i'm reporting in graphics
fellow i did undergrad at Northwestern
studied journalism and she is a madill
grad student so both from Northwestern
go cats and both of us have a background
in journalism we are starting with
injustice watch to really explore data
and everything and I dabbled an
interactive design while i was at
Northwestern as well but I think we're
both really coming at it as reporters so
that's a little bit about our background
so now I will talk about the story this
is a quote from this story it's
basically really about you know a
problem that Chicago has had in terms of
building the public trust in the police
department while aggressively fighting
crime and sort of a sentiment that we
had been finding in our reporting was
that too aggressively fight crime you
have to increase stops on the street it
was sort of like stops on the street as
a necessary evil in that vein to curbing
the violent crime rate and of course
summer months are the most violent in
Chicago and we were coming out with this
project in July so we wanted to explore
that topic and so our data was from the
ACLU of Illinois it's working on this
project was actually a dream because we
got the data from them pretty clean
about as clean as it could get and if
you I think the slides are going to be
sent out but the report can be found at
this URL but the ACL you put out in 2015
about stop and frisk in Chicago it
actually found that people in Chicago
were getting stopped at larger rates
than in other cities including New York
like even I think there were more stops
this study found in Chicago than there
were in New York not controlled for
population or anything so obviously this
is a something that's happening in the
city and so the data we have is about is
all the stops in the city that did not
end in arrest for a specific period in
2014 May through August and the reason
we have information on stops that did
not end in arrest as Chicago police are
required to fill out what they call a
contact card for each stop on the street
that does not end an arrest as a sort of
way to record you know where these stops
are happening and requires the police to
sort of keep track of the reasons that
they're stopping these people and the
number of stops we had from may to
august of 2014 that did not end an
arrest was just over it was about
so that's 256,000 stops in that period
that were not leading to arrest
ultimately and these are you know stops
police stops it's not just any
interaction of the police with the
civilian it stops yeah so and I should
note that those numbers have gone down
since 2014 we I don't remember what the
number was for 2015 but the reason we
wanted to look at this data from 2014
was it was sort of a peak for Chicago
and you know with the increasing
tensions and relations with police
relations with the community we wanted
to just give really reiterate and give a
glimpse of what it looks like when stops
are kind of you know getting excessive
in the city um so a little bit about the
data that we had again 256,000 stops we
had the street address to the nearest
hundred block so it was like if the stop
happened on 3912 north ashland we had 39
xxxx north ashland i think was kind of
an effort to you know keep private
residences and businesses private you
know not attract attention to that but
still give a good picture of what the
location was for a stop and we had race
sex resting officer type of stop so we
knew if it was vehicular or other and
then we had a few other things random ID
numbers we did not have the names of
people who were being stopped and we did
not have the descriptions of why the
officers were stopping people so that
was the first part of data that we had
from the ACLU and then the second part
was they did take 299 contact cards from
2013 that did have descriptions on them
just to give a picture like a random
sample of reasons cops were giving for
stopping people so these are two things
we visualized I'll show you in a second
what the final product looked like
but um I just wanted to kind of take you
all through the process of Emily and I
looking at this data how we kind of
handled it as reporters and then our
thought processes for eventually
visualizing it and giving a good
ultimate user experience to really
showcase the data you know the ACLU put
out this study but they didn't really
they visualize it in their study but the
full data set wasn't really accessible
to the public in any sort of way so
we've just really wanted to give a full
glimpse of what they were finding so
obviously we have a map I'm sure many of
you have seen it but um we wanted to
really make sure that we weren't just
making a map to make a map and so
because I'm a little bit hesitant always
as a graphics person to make maps I
think they're a little bit overused and
we really want to make sure that the
point we're trying to make has a
geospatial element to it before we make
a map and this obviously does we are
looking sort of at the effect that
policing has on particular communities
so we want to see if it's localized in
particular communities and what these
communities are so we decided to make a
map but obviously we don't have we we
know anecdotally from our reporting
people we're talking to that police are
you know stopping more people in these
communities than in others but we don't
know that from the numbers so our
process was really kind of design a
little bit plot out these points on a
map see if it says what we think it's
saying see if it makes the point that we
think we're making and then keep on
going from there so yeah we have 250,000
data points that's obviously a lot to
comprehend for an individual's brain and
also for a browser and we wanted to make
a client-side graphic for this so I kind
of knew from the very beginning I was
going to have to whittle this huge data
set
down into about 500 data points if I was
going to plot anything on a map so we
spent a few days figuring out really
what we wanted to do to get it down to
that manageable size and we thought
about sampling it but it didn't feel

p.span: statistically responsible to just take a

div.p: random sample of 500 from 250,000 so our
solution was to sort of pivot table you
know we both knew how to use excel and
we both you know spent a few days just
making all these like random pivot
tables trying to make sense of the data
and we eventually decided to pivot down
to clusters of stops on particular
blocks so basically what that kind of
looks like first of all we had to kind
of aggregate these three columns into
one column and just get street addresses
to the nearest hundred block and then
from there you can kind of see our
process here we got counts of the number
of stops per city block and then we also
kept race in there so we knew we wanted

p.span: a point and see if there's a

div.p: racial component to this so we had the
count of how many stops for each
specific race that we had in there and
that brought our data set that we were
working with down from 256,000 entries
to 28,000 entries so in effect there are
28 thousand city blocks that we have
counts for frequencies of stops for and
um obviously many of these have just
like one stop two stops three stops so
we decided to do 7777 stops per block
and above which brought our data set
down to 451 so basically there are 450
one of these blocks the nearest hundred
block that have 77 stops occurring on
them or more and I think the most was
around 575 which is a large number for
sure
so then I had to decide kind of what
background we wanted for our data what
kind of map we wanted for our data and I
knew I wanted to use d3 I used you three
a lot but we had to kind of decided we
want a street map or to look more
broadly at community areas or census
tracts is another thing that we thought
about for a second um and I thought a
street map would be really cool but
ultimately decided to do the community
area thing because loading the google
maps or openstreetmap base layer would
just be another thing to load on the
page and we had a lot going on and also
I this isn't like a huge deal i don't
think but there is that concern for
private businesses and residences we
felt like if we are plotting on actual
literal streets that people can see
there's still that component of people
looking at it being like oh this
particular businesses right here
whatever and we just didn't want to draw
attention to that unnecessarily so I got
a community areas geo JSON from city of
Chicago data portal and found this site
for geocoding the street addresses put
in all 451 street addresses got the
geographic coordinates which then go
pretty well with d3 and so this is the
map I ended up having and we wanted to
obviously check in with the map at this
point make sure that our data was
actually saying something which as you
can see there are clusters on the west
side on the south side and then there
are a few up here along in the loop and
the north loop but yeah mostly on the
south and west sides we had our largest
number was out of hair which I don't
actually remember why that was but it
took us a while to figure that out and
then yeah so we had basically each dot
represents you know
a block for end on a cluster of stops
anywhere within their range from 777 to
575 which is obviously a huge range so
when we updated the radiuses of the
stops to or the radiuses of these

happening on a block with the biggest
being 575 and the smallest being 77 you
know you obviously see that the blocks

the north side ones clusters and again
on the north side the neighborhoods that
you're seeing the most stops in our
Edgewater not Edgewater uptown lakeview

Rogers Park are very diverse

we had race data we wanted to look at

overwhelmingly african-americans being
stopped with a smattering of white
hispanic stops sort of on the lower west

dots up there on the north side as well
so at this point in the game we kind of

a point that that holds up and then the

the attributes are you know the
obviously the geographic coordinates the
